rss.title: Who Punched Arius?
rss.subtitle: Mom, tell me it's not true! This guy told me the jolly old fat man doesn't live at the top of the world...

subtitle_detail.value: Mom, tell me it's not true! This guy told me the jolly old fat man doesn't live at the top of the world...

transcription.full_transcript: Welcome to Catholic Stuff You Should Know. This is Deacon Mike. And it's John. Welcome. This is Catholic Stuff You Should Know. We changed the title like three weeks ago. Catholic Stuff. What, did I say it wrong? Yeah, Catholic Things. No, I didn't say it wrong. I usually say it wrong. Today, I said it correctly to the radio audience. Now, I was wondering today about... about CrossFit. CrossFit. Can you tell me what CrossFit is and why my body hurts so much? Well, the reason your body hurts so much is because once a month you do an exercise called CrossFit, and it's full intensive, very natural, and usually pretty short, but a pretty hardcore workout. But your problem is that you don't do anything for a month, and then you go... do an insanely difficult workout. And you're like, I don't understand why my body hurts. So the problem is doing it once a month. Not the workout itself, because my body tells me it's the workout that hurts. Yeah, you're like a little elf. You kind of show up once a month, run a couple miles, do all this weight, and then you come back a couple months later. I don't know why that's like an elf, but... Freakish. It's elfish. Yeah, it's elfish. Okay, so what are we talking about on Catholic stuff? We're talking about who punched Arius. Oh, that's a fun topic. Who punched Arius. And who is Arius? So we got to first figure out who the heck Arius is, and then we're going to figure out who punched him. Does that sound good? That sounds great. I like this topic. Okay, Arius was a priest in Alexandria, Egypt. Well, he was born in the year 256, and he died in 336. So he was born in the mid-third century and then died right around the mid-fourth century. A pretty important time for the church. A very important time for the church. A very important time. What happened at that period in the church? You had the most intensive persecutions under Diocletian and under several other emperors of Christians where they were just slaughtering Christians at the end of the third century. And then… In the beginning of the 4th century, right in the early 300s, you have the Edict of Milan, which is where Constantine makes Christianity legal. So it's like massive change, probably one of the most dramatic changes in the history of Christianity. So much so that you used to sympathize with Christians who get killed. Now we're worrying about somebody getting punched. Exactly. Exactly. They used to get killed. Now they're punching. And what we're going to find out today is they're punching each other. And we're going to figure out the reason for that. So. Arius is this priest in Alexandria. Now, Arius is, he's a scripture scholar. He's like you, Mike. He loves to study the Bible, except he gets in a little trouble because he starts to develop this theory. that Jesus is not God. Uh-oh. Right? So he has this theology that says, Jesus, who is the Son of God, is not the same being, does not share in the same being, the same divinity as God the Father. He's like, I look at the Bible, and I read about the Father, and I read about this guy, Jesus, and Jesus does not seem to me to be divine. They're too different. Right. Jesus is like a glorified Oprah, so to speak. He's just this kind of stage, dispensing wisdom freely. Kind of living a good life, good example, you know, loving. Okay, this is the part I forget. Does Arius say that Jesus is a man but not God, or he's God but one of many gods? He is a man, but he's kind of like got real powers. Just a powerful man. He's a really... Kind of blessed by God. Kind of like God's blessed. God himself. But he's not God. He's different than God. Okay. And so what happens is that this is not the case. This is not the belief of the church. This is not the truth. Jesus Christ is fully God and fully man. So essentially Arius is denying Jesus'divinity, that Jesus is God, and it becomes known as Arianism, right? Yeah. Well, here's a couple things. Arius is very influential, very popular, and he's a great musician, believe it or not. No, I didn't know that. Yeah, so what he does is he spreads his heresy, his teaching, his false teaching, by music. And it just takes off like wildfire. Do you remember any of those? I don't remember the songs. I think Rihanna is going to remake one of them here sometime soon. But exactly. Timbaland. Definitely had that piece. Timbaland, Aryan, Aryan. But it's spread like wildfire. So much so that a guy named... Athanasius, he says, I woke up, he was a bishop, he said, I woke up one morning to find the world had gone Aryan. That's one of his famous quotes from this is the early, early 300s. The whole world just picked up on this. And all of a sudden you have most of the Christians in the world are saying, Jesus isn't God. Jesus is just a man. So you've convinced me that this guy needs to get punched. But who punched him? Okay, so who punched him? So this is what happens. So he starts to get in trouble in his hometown of Alexandria. He flees to Palestine, right? And all the while he's like putting out the tunes and he's like, you know, all this music and he's spreading this heresy. And people are going for it, man. They're loving it. They're just like, this is so great. So he's spreading, spreading. Well, eventually they grab him and they drag him to a place called Nicaea because the emperor Constantine is like, I just made Christianity legal. Now you guys are screwing it up. Right. And now all these Christians believe a heresy. So the emperor Constantine says he pulls all of the bishops of the world together, which is only about 300 who come to this council at the time. It's a lot smaller church at this time. gathers them all in a place called Nicaea, which is in the far eastern coast of Turkey, right before you get into continental Europe. He says, we're going to meet there. We're going to figure this out. So they drag Arius to this meeting, right, to the Council of Nicaea, a famous council, because it's the first of what's called ecumenical councils. Ecumenical is a fancy word that comes from the Greek word for worldwide. So this is a universal council, ecumenical council. And it's the first ecumenical council. The first time this has ever happened, there's been like 20 or something. Tell me, 22? Something like that in the history of the church. This was the first one in 325 A.D. in the town of Nicaea. All right, so the Council of Nicaea. So you've got all these bishops there, two of which are important. Athanasius, who we talked about earlier, who was one of the first people to hate this guy. He's also the bishop of Alexandria. So he is personally angry about this guy, Arius, who's one of his priests from Alexandria. Right? Right. Another interesting guy is this guy named St. Nicholas. Who's going to come into our story? Okay. St. Nicholas. St. Nicholas. St. Nicholas of Myra, or Mari, right? Now, is this the same St. Nick, the good St. Nick who comes down the chimney? It's the same good St. Nick. We're going to talk about this just in a second. Yeah, he becomes Santa Claus in the Protestant world about a thousand years later, but we're going to get to that in a little bit. So, St. Nicholas. A thousand years before. A trim, a trim, a crossfit St. Nick. A crossfit St. Nick. Shows up at the counter. He was doing, you know, like a... kettle bells and he was doing push press. And he's like, okay, time to take a break. Goes to the Council of Nicaea. He's sitting in the council and Arius starts running his mouth about this heresy. And what does he do? He stands up in the middle thing, walks over to him and just decks him. Drops. These are bishops. This is Athanasius punching Arius. No, St. Nicholas punched Arius. Athanasius. St. Nicholas. St. Nicholas. just dropped him right there in the middle of the thing. And it's just like this massive riot breaks out. But this is a bishop and a saint punching this heretic in the face. That is awesome. That is awesome. I love it. This is one of the most fantastic things. We think of saints as like St. Therese. They're just pious and quiet. And they don't think of him like punching in the face, right? Okay. Let me ask you this. Can you imagine? My friend Brian Larkin listens to bad music. Can I punch him in the face? You know, some of that music is really bad, and I would say I don't know if it's heretical, but it's Well, effinescence might be or whatever. I think that's I don't know. Take that up with your spiritual director. Okay. Here's the question. Why was St. Nicholas so pissed off? So we've got to look at his life because that will explain why he punched Ares in the face. He ends up causing this they throw him out of the council for a bit. He comes back, and then they hail him as this great because he was one of the turning points in the council. At the end of the Council of Nicaea, they write the Creed of Nicaea, which formally rejects Arianism. So it says this is a heresy, and it says Jesus is divine. And that creed that we got from 325 from the Council of Nicaea, from St. Nicholas Punching Arius, is the same one we pray every single Sunday at Mass. The Nicene Creed. Same one 1,200 years later. That's pretty sweet. So this makes a huge difference. The way you understand Jesus is going to be. It's a huge difference. And many Catholics right now, we kind of treat Jesus like that. Like, oh, he's kind of a nice guy. I think we all have this in us as modern Catholics. It's like, he's just a nice guy. But he's not really God. He's not really God. Come on, that's a little crazy. Maybe like the best guy who I know. Maybe like the best guy. Yeah, Buddha's number two. Jesus is number one. That's great, you know? So if I hear somebody say that, I can punch them in the face. Punch them in the face. Absolutely. Okay, wait a minute, though. Santa Claus is the jolliest old man that we know. Okay. How did St. Nick, who punched Arius in the face, get the reputation of being this jolly, you know, like fuzzy gift giver? Good question. Let's start with the life of St. Nicholas. He was born in 270, 80, so right around the same time as Arius. He was a little younger than Arius, right? Okay. And he was born in modern-day Turkey. And he... he had this conversion in his life. He was about 20 or so. And then eventually he was made bishop. So at the time of the Nicene Creed, at the time of the Council of Nicaea, he was a bishop. That's why he went to the council. Right. Because he was the bishop of this place called Myra. All right. So he's the bishop. But here's the reason why he was so pissed off at Ares. Because his whole life, he had been thrown in prison time and time again and persecuted and threatened to death by the Roman emperors, like Diocletian, before Constantine made Christianity. So this guy had been suffering for like 30 years, and then all of a sudden this guy, Ares, starts running his mouth, and he's like, I didn't suffer and almost get killed by Romans for a guy who's not even God. I did it for Jesus Christ, who is God incarnate. Oh, yeah. That's why he's like, this is personal. So he goes to the council, and he decks him. Well, he ends up dying in 347, but St. Nicholas is famous because he was this kind of secret gift giver. He was, you know, as... Shannon Gunning would say his love language was gift-giving. It wasn't quality time or something like that. He would just kind of secretly give these gifts to people. There's all these amazing other stories. Unfortunately, we don't have time to go into them, but you can just Wikipedia this or Catholic Encyclopedia this and find out all kinds of stuff on his life. But he dies on December 6, 347. So December 6 becomes his feast day, right? He's made a saint, and on December 6 we celebrate his feast day. In the Middle Ages, what happens is that after the Protestant Reformation, the Protestants, the Catholics are celebrating St. Nicholas Day on December 6th. And the Protestants are like, you know what, we need to subvert this and mess this up. So they take the Dutch word Sinterklaas, which is how you would pronounce St. Nicholas. Oh, by the way, the name Nicholas, if there's any Nicholases listening, Nico, Nike, and Laos. Victory of the people. That's two Greek words, Nike and Laos. Victory, isn't that cool? A little side fact. A little side fact. So the victory of the people comes when Nicholas punches Arius in the face. There you go. So that's what that's But you were getting to Santa Claus. Sorry, that's the name Nicholas. I thought that was interesting. So we get to Santa I'm hearing sleigh bells in my ear. Okay, we get to Santa Sinterklaas, right? This Dutch rendering of the name Nikolaus, which is a Greek name, right? So Sinterklaas. translates into the English as Santa Claus. And then what happens is Protestants develop this whole kind of caricature of the saint. It's rooted in his good works and in his gift-giving, but they kind of turn him into this other weird thing, and then he gets turned into this whole material thing and kind of slips a couple weeks later into Christmas. Catholics still celebrate St. Nicholas Day on December 6th, and you actually meet a lot of Catholic families who still do this. Yeah, with the shoes outside the door. But yeah, now we've made him into this kind of freaky, jolly Christmas thing, right? Who's actually supplanted Jesus in Christmas. So not only did St. Nicholas get screwed, but so did Jesus now. Right, he's taken all the warm feelings from the little baby in the manger and made them... fat man's cookie feelings. Exactly. Exactly. So yeah, it's a, it's an interesting story. Nicholas is an interesting guy. He's a, he's in Italy now of all places. I think all saints end up in Italy eventually. Just, you know, they, they come and they get their relics. And so they took him from Turkey. Yeah. They took him from Turkey and like, I'm sorry. They took him from Turkey in 1087 and dragged him over to, um, Bari, Italy. So if you're ever in Southwestern Italy, check him out. He's hanging out there. Jolly. And. Sometimes violent. Old St. Nicholas.

summarization.results: Arius, a priest in Alexandria, propagated the belief that Jesus is not divine, leading to the emergence of Arianism. This doctrine was refuted at the Council of Nicaea in 325 A.D., where St. Nicholas famously punched Arius. St. Nicholas, known for his generosity, later evolved into the modern-day figure of Santa Claus, associated with Christmas gift-giving traditions.
